intro: Treubella amplexans, commonly known as the clinging mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that belongs to the Viscaraceae family. It typically grows on the branches of other plants, such as trees and shrubs, and derives some of its nutrients from its host through specialized root structures called haustoria. The plant is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and white or pinkish flowers that bloom in late spring. Its berries, which are usually red or yellow, are an important food source for birds and other wildlife. Treubella amplexans is often found in temperate regions and can be a common sight in forested areas.
